entity: Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services
entity_raw_name: IX.	Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services
source_file: A_80_6_SECT.1.PART AB_CONSOLIDATED_FASCICLE_ADVANCED COPY TO ACABQ_22 MAY 2025.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services is responsible for providing confidential, impartial and independent conflict resolution services to address work-related issues of staff members and non-staff personnel, upon request. In doing so, the United Nations Ombudsman makes an essential contribution to making the Organization a productive, healthy and enabling workplace.

The mandate of the Office derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and/or decisions, including resolutions 55/258 and 56/253. The Office was further strengthened by the Assembly, pursuant to its resolutions 61/261 and 62/228, to create an integrated and geographically decentralized Office. By its resolution 73/276, the Assembly requested the Secretary-General to establish, within existing resources, a pilot project to offer access to informal dispute resolution services to non-staff personnel. By its resolution 78/248, the Assembly decided to regularize the pilot project for access by non-staff personnel to the services of the Office, within existing resources.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this Office contributes, is to ensure the effective functioning of the Organization by enhancing harmony in the workplace through an efficient and effective option for staff and non-staff personnel to seek redress to grievances.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Office will:

(a)	Provide the full range of conflict resolution services to United Nations staff and non-staff personnel in three core areas: address workplace grievances from staff and non-staff personnel through case intervention; engage with relevant stakeholders to provide systemic feedback for improvements in the workplace; and strengthen the ability of staff and non-staff personnel to address workplace conflict effectively through capacity building initiatives;

(b)	Ensure the global staff and non-staff personnel have access to the informal pillar of the administration of justice and to informal conflict resolution services, including through the provision of services in all six official languages of the United Nations;
(c)	Conduct outreach efforts to raise awareness of the importance of informal dispute resolution as a preferred first step in the Organization;
(d)	Promote and facilitate healthy dialogue among colleagues through the delivery of its workshops on “civility, communication and community”.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more harmonious and collaborative work environment for United Nations staff and non-staff personnel;
(b)	More productive and more effective functioning of the Organization;
(c)	Improved understanding by staff and non-staff personnel and managers of the importance of resilience and flexibility in promoting a harmonious workplace.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	All staff and non-staff personnel, including those in supervisory functions, avail themselves of opportunities to resolve workplace issues  through the established informal mechanisms;

(b)	All staff and non-staff personnel observe applicable United Nations regulations and rules regarding the terms and conditions of employment and apply lessons learned from decisions of the United Nations Dispute Tribunal and the United Nations Appeals Tribunal;
(c)	Caseload trends remain stable.

With regard to cooperation with other entities and inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will continue to cooperate with the network of ombudsmen and mediators of the United Nations system so as to contribute to improved system-wide cohesion and impact in the area of conflict resolution in the workplace. The Office will also focus on building stronger collaboration with the formal system of the administration of justice to explore opportunities for more referrals from the formal to the informal pillar.

The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. For example, the Office will continue to integrate a gender perspective into the provision of conflict resolution services and the identification of systemic issues to provide feedback on gender inequities, as observed in cases brought forward. The Office will continue to support the implementation of the system wide strategy on gender equality and empowerment of women. The Office also compiles gender-disaggregated data.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will work to ensure that it takes into account the needs of persons with disabilities, facilitating their full and effective participation in the activities of the Office and ensure that the relevant content, such as information conveyed through its online platforms, is available to persons with disabilities. The Office will maintain accessibility features on the website that benefits users with both short and long-term disabilities in collaboration with the Department of Global Communications.
Evaluation activities
An evaluation of client satisfaction, conducted by the Office and completed in 2024, has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

In response to the results of the evaluation referenced above, the Office will work closely with stakeholders, and staff and non-staff personnel to raise awareness of the ‘informal first” approach as an important first step to effectively resolve workplace disputes.  The benefits of this approach are numerous, including an amicable, confidential, cost-effective and time-efficient approach to resolve disputes.  The Office will continue to deliver information sessions, including targeted outreach to increase awareness of informal conflict resolution mechanisms and building conflict competence skills by engaging staff and non-staff personnel in dialogue and promoting actions to improve workplace behaviour where everyone can thrive in dignity and mutual respect.
An evaluation of client satisfaction, to be conducted by the Office, is planned for 2026.
Programme performance in 2024
Managing workplace conflict better through capacity and skill-building activities

The principle of dignity is a cornerstone of the Organization, as reinforced in the staff regulations which provides that “staff members shall uphold and respect the principles set out in the Charter including faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person and in the equal rights of men and women”. In its systemic observations, the Office has consistently highlighted concerns related to issues of dignity and respect. Those observations have also pointed to the impact of such issues on team climate and morale, stressing the need to foster an inclusive and respectful work environment.  In 2024, the Office organized a workshop on dignity, focusing on the connection between dignity and civility in the workplace, and explored how communication enhances or undermines dignity.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 1.XXIII).
Performance measure: number of personnel equipped to manage workplace conflict
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: improved access to mediation services
Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The Office’s work contributed to 103 mediation services conducted through a decentralized approach, which did not meet the planned target of 120 mediation services. The target was not met due primarily to the underutilization of referrals from the formal system.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 1.XXIV).
Performance measure: number of mediation services conducted through a decentralization of services (annual)
Result 2: United Nations non-staff personnel have access to informal conflict resolution services – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
The Office’s work contributed to 258 non-staff personnel utilizing informal conflict resolution services, which exceeded the planned target of 190.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 1.XXV).
Performance measure: number of non-staff personnel utilizing informal conflict resolution services (annual)
Result 3: increased access of services to staff in the field – Proposed programme plan for 2026

The Office continues to mainstream lessons learned and best practices, adjusting and adapting its processes, including the use of virtual platforms, where appropriate, to meet personnel to discuss their concerns. While virtual platforms and activities enabled the Office to continue to deliver its services, it was found to be an inadequate replacement for in-person interaction. Given the sensitive and confidential nature of conflict resolution, personnel are often reluctant to use virtual platforms to discuss their concerns. Moreover, technical difficulties, including bandwidth, network and connectivity issues, impeded access for many staff, in particular in remote duty stations, to the Office’s support. The Office will use virtual modes as a complement to in-person interaction.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Office was that the closer the Office can deliver its services to staff, particularly to those in the deep field and hardship duty stations, the more effective it can be. In applying the lesson, the Office will deliver a combination of initial virtual interaction, followed by in-person meetings as necessary to maximize the benefits to staff in the deep field and hardship duty stations from the services offered by the Office.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 1.XXVI).
Performance measure: number of informal conflict services accessed by field staff
Legislative mandates
The list below, which was reviewed in the preparation of the proposed programme budget, provides all mandates entrusted to the programme.
General Assembly resolutions

The proposed regular budget resources for 2026, including the breakdown of resource changes, as applicable, are reflected in tables 1.121 to 1.123.

Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in tables 1.124 to 1.126 and figure 1.XXVII.

As reflected in table 1.124 (1), the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $4,388,100, reflecting an increase of $500 compared with the approved budget for 2025. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

children.text: Distribution of proposed resources for 2026
(Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)
Explanation of variances by factor –  – Overall resource changes –  – Other changes –
As shown in table 1.124 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $500, which relates to higher standard price of ICT charges for non-field personnel outside of UNHQ.
Other assessed resources

As reflected in tables 1.124 (2) and 1.125 (2), other assessed resources amount to $2,946,000. The resources would complement regular budget resources and provide for the requirements indicated in the report of the Secretary-General on the budget for the support account for peacekeeping operations for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026 (A/79/783).
Extrabudgetary resources

As reflected in table 1.124 (3), extrabudgetary resources amount to $110,000. The non-post resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to support the delivery of its mandates, including the provision of conflict resolution services to the International Court of Justice, the World Meteorological Organization and the International Trade Centre in accordance with the memorandum of understanding.
The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Office, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.

Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking of air travel is reflected in table 1.127. The office will strengthen its efforts to ensure the advance booking of tickets in line with the air travel policy and improve its compliance rate.
Compliance rate
(Percentage)
